Award.AwardTitle: Strings, Branes and the Search for Unification
Award.AbstractNarration: The three researchers on this proposal propose a program investigating fundamental aspects of string theory and M-theory and their implications for particle phenomenology and cosmology. One aspect of this project deals with the construction and implications for phenomenology of flux backgrounds for heterotic strings, which they denote by torsional heterotic geometries. The heterotic string is a natural setting to construct models of particle phenomenology. However, the role played by background H-flux has not been unraveled yet, even though it may profoundly influence the 4d low-energy effective action. In this project the PIs employ a strategy to obtain the first large class of torsional heterotic geometries by explicitly constructing their metric. The number of torsional heterotic geometries turns out to be of the same order of magnitude as the number of type II flux backgrounds. The explicit examples display an N=2,1,0, supersymmetry in 4d. Flux changes the 4d phenomenology and the PIs are investigating the implications of this new strategy. They propose strategies to obtain chiral matter and novel ways to break the E8 gauge symmetry to the standard model gauge group. These backgrounds stand a much better chance of admitting tractable world-sheet descriptions compared to the type II counterparts. The precise implications of torsional geometries for algebraic geometry such as the calculation of the exact moduli space of torsional geometries, the resolution of singularities, the construction of vector bundles and ultimately three-generation models with stabilized moduli is proposed. Evidence of string theory from cosmology will be explored in terms of a brane inflation model. String theory models make predictions for gravitational radiation and lead to strong non-Gaussianities in the cosmic microwave background. Several aspects of the duality between M-theory compactifications to 4d space-time and its boundary conformal field theories (CFT) will also be explored. The research also includes a systematic construction and possible string/M-theory embedding of new supergravities in diverse dimensions, exploration of infinite dimensional symmetries, and their implications for integrability in string theory in nontrivial backgrounds. Finally, the important question of the uniqueness of string theory as a candidate for a quantum theory of gravity will be addressed in the context of 3d quantum gravity and its dual CFT. The broader impacts of the project are related to the importance of testing string theory as theory that can describe experiments. The PIs are looking for ways to understand the experimental tests for Cosmology and particle physics. In the LHC era and with new satellites becoming available, it is vital to work out the connections between physics at the Planck scale and TeV scale physics, while advancing our knowledge in string cosmology. The final goal of this project is to unravel the imprints of high-energy physics onto our 4d world. At the same time the program is expected to have a profound impact on different areas of mathematics. Two of the PIs have just written an important book on string theory and M theory with John Schwartz, one of the founders of superstring theory. All three PIs are involved in disseminating information about string theory by giving talks at workshops and conferences as well as organizing workshops. They are also involved in collaborations with mathematicians to understand the topology and geometry of string theory.

This project finances the research work of 3 PIs, Katrin Becker, Melanie Becker and Ergin Sezgin, as well as in part the work of their graduate students and postdocs.

1) M.Becker has been working with her students (Ning Su and Yaniel Cabrera) and her postdocs (Sera Cremonini and Waldemar Schulgin) in projects related to the Kerr/CFT correspondence and its generalizations and applications to condensed matter systems (for which many of the techniques used in Kerr/CFT can be applied). Kerr/CFT is a generalization of AdS/CFT for which the symmetries underlying the holographic duality are more intricate. This "more general" duality allows us to study aspects of black hole physics or condensed matter physics, that would be difficult to solve due to strong coupling, using a weakly couple dual model.
So far we have applied the Kerr/CFT duality to study the scattering of 3 scalars off the black hole background and we have generalized the calculation to fermions that are more interesting from the phenomenology point of view.

We are currently studying gauge fields in such geometries as well as the generalization to conformal field theories originating from modified boundary conditions in the bulk theory.

2) K. Becker: 
To explore the imprints on particle physics and cosmology arising from a fundamental theory based on strings it it necessary to work with the most general class of solutions to the string theory equations. This class is much larger than is currently known, as has been found by Katrin Becker in collaboration with Savdeep Sethi. They constructed a large class of new solutions, which they denoted by torsional heterotic geometries, which are complex mathematical spaces used to curl up the extra dimensions of space-time which string theory predicts. Even though these spaces are very small and at this moment not observable they determine how observed physics looks like. Some of nature's deepest mysteries, like the reason why there are three space and one time dimension, may find its ultimate explanation within these solutions to heterotic string theory. Moreover, by considering the most general class of solutions, namely those including a background tensor field or flux, it might be possible to explain why the proton, a fundamental constituent of the atomic nucleus is stable. What singles torsional heterotic geometries out is that these solutions exist not only classically. It may be possible to formulate them as full quantum gravity theories. At this moment string theory gives rise to millions and millions of possible universes, with all possible properties and it is not clear why the one we live in is singled out. This is sometimes called the ``Landscape'' of string theory solutions. It would be extremely beautiful if the rules of quantum gravity would single out one or a few of those solutions, ultimately explaining why the universe around us looks the way it does.

3) E. Sezgin:
An important success of string theory is to provide a consistent theory of quantum gravity coupled to matter. The low energy description requires the large string tension limit. In this limit, supersymmetric version of Einstein gravity, namely supergravity theory, and its coupling to matter fields, arises in ten or eleven dimensions. The four dimensional physics then emerges by various mechanisms such as spontaneous compactification in which the extra dimensions are very small, or braneworld scenarios in which the four dimensional spacetime is considered as a 3-dimensional extended object, 3-brane, moving in target spacetime.
